No matter how many reviews you write, sometimes there's always going to be that one series that, while decent, is difficult to recommend to anyone in particular. So, with that short introduction, let's get into the review...
-Story:
The story mainly follows Willem, who is one of (I think) the last humans alive on earth. After a series of cataclysmic events that ravaged the earth and left it uninhabitable, he was frozen in suspended animation, until he was woken up many years after said events. He wakes to find that all humans have been extinct for a long period of time, and that all other living racesnow live on floating islands in the sky to protect themselves from the surface (Willem's former home) which is overrun with monsters. While taking odd jobs, he meets Chtholly, a young girl who turns out to be a leprechaun. In this world, leprechauns are essentially sacrificial weapons tasked with protecting the citizens of the sky islands from the beasts that dwell below. To accomplish their tasks, they wield magical swords called "dug weapons", which are used to slay the beasts. The story primarily follows these two as they become acquainted with each other and start working together in the same military weapons facility. Along the way, they each have to deal with their own internal struggles and emotional baggage, while also trying to come to terms with not only the harsh reality that they're faced with, but also their developing feelings toward one another.


So, to change up the format a little, I'm going to list what I liked and disliked about the story in bullet points:


+ The leprechauns face a cruel and short existence, which is shown in detail. They each know that they won't live long lives, but they still try to find what little happiness and meaning they can in their short lifespans.

+ The relationship between Willem and Chtholly is done VERY well. Unlike many anime, it feels natural, and not forced in the slightest. They both start out as friends, but develop into much more, while trying to change themselves for the sake of the other.

+ The world is written in a way that makes it interesting, leaving you wanting to know more. 

+ There's racial tension between the "featured" (lizards, fur-people, etc) and the "non-featured" (trolls, leprechauns, and Willem, a human), which I thought was a great touch. 

- There's far too many unexplained aspects relating to the inner-workings of the world and it's history. It's an interesting world, but we're only shown very little of past events or how many things in the world came to be.

- Definitely some plot holes here and there.

- There's multiple plot devices that are introduced but never utilized in the slightest (such as the dug weapon lapis-something something)

- Many of the emotional moments come off as being very melodramatic. 

- The few "fanservice" and lewd moments come off as being a bit odd and out of place. Multiple characters also accuse Willem of being a pedophile (since he works in a mansion full of young female leprechauns), and while it may be intended as a joke, the humor is fairly dry.

- The ending. I'm not going to spoil it, but for me, it leaves a lot to be desired. It's not that it's bad, but it leaves a few things up to the viewer's interpretation (which some may see as a good thing). 


Characters:


Willem is your (somewhat) typical protagonist with a strong sense of justice. He has a tragic past and is plagued by feelings of regret and guilt for not being able to save his friends and family in the past. Then there's Chtholly, an emotional, caring, and reckless girl who values her friends and puts her life on the line to protect them. She also acts as a big-sister for many of the younger leprechauns. These two see the bulk of the character development in this story, while other characters remain pretty much static throughout the entirety of the series. There's also quite a few characters who just fill the role for their assigned archetype. Many of the characters also aren't properly characterized or fleshed out, making them seem fairly bland and unimportant. 


Sound and Animation:


The animation is done by studio Satelight and C2C and honestly, it's quite good. I didn't notice any off-models, and most scenes were detailed and vivid in color. The few fight scenes in the series, while not the best I've seen, are still done relatively well. 


The music in this series is...interesting. The opening and ending songs are fitting and fairly good (albeit forgettable), and the OST itself doesn't really stick out much, but blends in well with the majority of scenes. The "interesting" aspect that I mentioned is that, this anime uses Celtic Woman's "Scarborough Fair" as an insert song at a couple points in the story. I was actually surprised to hear it, and even more surprised at how well it fit into the theme and overall focus of the series itself (namely, Chtholly's desire to be with Willem).


Conclusion:


There is no doubt that Suka Suka is an anime with a number of flaws that hold it back from becoming a truly wonderful story. It also seemed like the director was unsure of the direction that he/she wanted to take the series, which puts it into a weird middle ground. Despite my criticisms with this anime, I still can't say that I didn't find some enjoyment in it. If you can look past it's various flaws, at it's core, Suka Suka does do a good job at showcasing it's central themes of self-salvation, mortality, and the pursuit of happiness. If those themes interest you, and you don't mind wading through the melodrama and clumsily written story, this anime might hold something worthwhile for you.

This show is very underrated and deserves more attention. This show explains a brand new story, setting, and plot to us. However there are some generic aspects to it such as a mildly forced relationship but I can see how they end up together. The beginning is a very kind opening to any viewer and gives us the names of the characters and setting. 
However I personally enjoy this show for the mystery aspect of the story and how the beast's came to be. Willem's past is also interesting and his past keeps getting shown throughout the story to give the watcher a more interestingtime to think about the plot. The present time of Chtholly and the other girls help support the story but also give the story the main action scenes that we enjoy. 


The romance aspect is rather fast paced but I however enjoyed the development of the characters personally. However I don't think this story is focused around romance, but more mystery. Every episode cracks a new thought the original writer gave and give us more and more details of what this world is about. 


Overall this is my favorite show this season and like many other great underrated shows after running out of episodes I felt empty and bored.

Oh boy... SukaSuka or Shuumatsu Nani Shitemasu ka? Isogashii Desu ka? Sukutte Moratte Ii Desu Ka?... I remember when I was still a teenage boy, getting into anime and watching several shows of both classic and modern. I sat there as I pondered into the screen of my tablet, as I could hear from my computer the sounds of a "What will I be watching for this season" video. The selection was a bit interesting, but one had caught my eye. This was the one. After the first episode aired, I watched the subbed version and I was hooked. This is... without a doubt, ahidden gem for me for this season.\n
SukaSuka is an anime with elements such as romance, tragedy and drama that enters a post-apocalyptic world where we see that the main character, Willem, is the last one of his race. He has the past of a miserable brave. After waking up from his "slumber", he finds himself in a world where humanity has been wiped out. He discovers himself saving a girl who has sky blue hair and ocean eyes, Chtholly, who later asks him if she could grant one of her wishes. He is then offered a job for the military to watch over "secret weapons". Willem soon finds out that he is assigned alongside Chtholly, who tells him that she and the others of the warehouse they live in are the secret weapons. Their tragic story starts from there.\n
Upon the first episode, we're thrown into an opening where we see the future. We see a girl with red hair walking down a corridor on an airship while everyone in there is fighting off beasts. Her eyes are complete hollow while we get a scene of a man desperately trying to save a girl while he's falling. The girl with red hair starts talking about the man before she then jumps off the airship, and then, we're shown the title screen. This scene was perhaps, one of the more powerful ones, it showed us what was happening, and the dialogue was enough to make us understand what we were in for. It had a great OST that had me piqued at first. "Always in my Heart" was a great song for this scene and I knew that this... was something I would cry at.\n
Now, I've only given out that scene for an analyzation because I don't want to spoil the whole entire story for you or else it'll be not that fun for you to explore this own path yourself. I will be using several scenes, but they won't be enough to spoil the entire story.\n
SukaSuka is a beautiful show. It holds one of the best OSTs and is one of my favorites, lying close to my heart. After watching this show side by side with others, I gradually became invested with its story and characters. I knew something was going to happen, yet I was oblivious of it due to how deep I was invested with the show. In the next paragraph, I will begin by explaining why this show is so special to me with the starting scene after the opening sequence on episode 1.\n
At a distant town, we can see a sky-blue haired girl chasing down a cat with a gem in its mouth. After she corners the cat, the cat jumps on her and she is thrown off balance. She falls towards the road of the area she's in, and a man rushes to catch her. The man is Willem and the woman is Chtholly. Willem helps out Chtholly with the island's path. During this, we get Scarborough Fair playing, this time, the song has the words edited out from "her" to "him". The song brought harmony to my ears while we got to see their adventures on the island.\n
I chose this scene since it was pretty big. It had a foreshadowing of Willem desiring to be with Chtholly through the usage of Scarborough Fair. We also got to see that Chtholly wish is also teased. This gets us hooked on the show, and we continue watching. For me, this part established a bit of the two characters. This part is one of my favorite ones in this series.\n
SukaSuka is one of those shows that can play around with your heart with the possibility that they can crush it or tickle it. Each scene in there is meaningful and further establishes the character. By the end of this show, I was probably crying for a good ten minutes with my fist clenched and my mouth closed. I was desperately trying to not cry yet I broke.\n
Here are my ratings and my explanations for the show:\n
Story - 8.3/10. The show ended off disappointing, I would say. We cut from a really sad scene to a panel of scenes where we just see Limeskin satisfied at the two soldiers who had died on the battlefield and the aftermath of the battle... The scene was a bit offputting. We ended up with no explanation at the end with a baby being found. I supposed that these questions would be only answered if I read the light novel, which was probably what they wanted to get us to do.\n
Art - 9.7/10. The art was mesmerizing to look at. If we saw the scene with Willem tuning the swords, that could be one of the beautiful scenes.\n
Sound - 10/10. To me, I remember SukaSuka through its amazing OST. Each song fits the show and conveys a deep message to us. That's what I love SukaSuka for.\n
Characters - 9.5/10. Could've improved a bit better with some scenes that were made in the LN. I know that the studio couldn't probably do it, but some of the scenes could've helped us love the characters more. Every major girl in here can be argued for being the best girl of this series.\n
Enjoyment - 9.8/10. I will definitely remember this ride that I had in 2017. I will always remember when. The characters are woven always in my heart. The only problem was with the disappointment I had at the ending, which kinda ruined how I felt.\n
Overall - 9.3/10. Unfortunately, I would've liked to rate this higher, but I don't think I can with that ending.\n
SukaSuka is without a doubt something I will recommend to my friends. It was able to break my heart and leave me depressed for almost five days before I was able to get back up.\n
I'm pretty sure that another rewatch for SukaSuka will happen during this year - in 2019 - however, we'll just wait and see.\n
During writing this, I've noticed that some of the reviews on here were negative. I can understand their tastes and respect their decision. However, if you're not interested in watching SukaSuka by just their review ratings and that, I highly suggest that you should watch it and see it for yourself. SukaSuka was supported a lot around the world when it aired.\n
After finishing the anime, I highly recommend the light novel. It definitely will be worth it!

This show was something else. It could have used better world building and lore development and I would have liked to see more secondary characters get more time to grow. At times it can be fairly confusing and attempts to be overly complex without bothering to explain itself. But for all its faults, I really loved this show.
The story centers on one Willem Kmetsch, the last human being alive in a world that was brought to ruin by enigmatic monsters called "beasts." What remains of the world is now populated by humanoid animal people and mythical creatures like goblins (there's a troll involved but shelooks like a normal person). Willem's life takes a dramatic turn when he's assigned as caretaker to a group of "leprechauns", young girls who wield weapons capable of killing the beasts. He comes to love and care for these girls like they were his own daughters, and he forms a very intimate relationship with one of the older girls, Chtholly.


Let me tell you something, this show is sad. It's about girls who are seemingly fated to die in battle finding something to live for, pursuing their own ideals of happiness despite their tragic lot in life. The love that forms between Willem and Chtholly is both heartwarming and heartbreaking to witness and by the story's end you might find yourself cursing this godforsaken world they inhabit. That's not to say that the plot is entirely sad, as there's also a lot of hope here and the promise that we can leave this world better than we found it.


As far as animation goes, the show is pretty adequate. The character models  are fairly well realized, especially the animal people and the leprechauns. The show's world is also interesting to behold, from medieval-esque cities in the sky to esoteric spiritual realms. There's also some cool visual effects as the leprechauns tap into their true power. There's a touch of CGI in the show and it's not very good, but it's not there very often so it's tolerable.


I really enjoyed the show's score; it ranges from playful and charming to haunting and mournful. Since the events of the plot will make you run the gauntlet emotionally, it would only make sense that the soundtrack also does. Let me just say one song in particular stood out to me; a rendition of "Scarborough Fair" by Yamada Tamaru. Simply beautiful. Even if you don't watch the show, look up her performing it; mesmerizing.


So, why does this show lose some points with me? It doesn't explain itself all that well. There are some plot points that I felt came out of left field or just weren't conveyed properly. What's worse is that the show sometimes acts as if we should somehow magically know this stuff; I didn't read the light novel and I don't plan to, so help me out here! I think there's a fascinating and deep lore worth exploring here, but the problem is that us anime viewers are only given a very small window to observe it through.


When all it said and done, this show has several flaws that might alienate some potential viewers. It's far from perfect but I very much enjoyed it despite its imperfections. It's a bittersweet story of love, fate and loss that will tug on your heartstrings (the last shot of the show in particular got me). If you're willing to overlook some flaws, I think you'll find WorldEnd/SukaSuka to be a show that will leave a mark on your heart.

Wasted potential sums this show up. The premise could have led to so much more if the story wasn't so mired is cliché and tropes so overplayed you can tell pretty much the beats of the story form the 3rd episode.
Honestly, this show is ok. Nothing special. Nowt to write home about. An overall lack of depth to any and all characters makes them feel flat, two-dimensional and difficult to become invested in. 
The world lacks fleshing out, feeling hollow and empty. exposition is sparse when desired and when apparent is dealt with clumsily. 
If you are bored then maybe have a look, but honestlythere are many shows out there that create a world similar to this, with the same time-frame per episode and yet still create an intricate, nuanced universe that you can't help being pulled into. TLDRN: Go watch Overlord.

Shuumatsu Nani Shitemasu ka? Isogashii desu ka? Sukutte Moratte Ii desu ka?
There will be spoilers. 
This was a show which I put off watching for a long time because I expected it to be an emotionally punishing experience, I ended up watching it over the course of two (working) days and in the end it left me with one (long-winded) question:
Is this show an earnest and cack-handed attempt to deliver a tragic tale of redemption through the salvation of others or is it a brazenly cynical and exploitative mashup of stock tropes and pre-packed themes that are verging on the Pavlovian?
So, what is this show?Imagine a pastiche of Saikano or Gunslinger Girl and Neon Genesis Evangelion in the now inescapable Isekai setting. Rather than a smooth flowing narrative it has juddering pacing that pulls you in at times and then ejects confused and annoyed moments later. The show is thick with utterly needless elements that provide filler and remind us that MC is a Nice Guy(TM) but which ultimately do little to advance the story, which itself is not bad. Sometimes a tragic show needs some light elements to break up the bleakness, lay it on too thick though and you suffer from clutter and a tempo that's all over the place, sometimes less is more.


Tl;dr A show with the potential to be a moving experience which whether by hook or crook failed to deliver its promise. (and I think that on balance it was probably cack-handed rather than exploitative.)




[SPOILERS]





Your premise, dear viewer, is; Mary Sue MC with super powers, because reasons, and the living weapon girls he must save, live in a world of floating islands while the earth below is populated by an incomprehensible alien enemy with which there can be no reasoning and which seeks to wipe out humanity. Oh, also all of humanity is already dead (apart from our superhuman Hero, naturally) and the sky islands are populated by furries, lizardmen, goblins and golems, because reasons. Oh and there's some kind of racial tension between the aforementioned characters and the characters who aren't furries, lizardmen, goblins and golems and instead look like humans but they're not called humans, because again, reasons. The only purpose for this sub-plot seems to be to remind us that MC is a Nice Guy(TM) and to provide light relief, like rubbing the belly of a furry is arousing to the furry and that's funny, rather than a sexual assault, again, MC is a Nice Guy(TM), not a predator with a messiah complex.


So, the emotional thrust of the story, like Saikano or Gunslinger Girl, the greatest weapon is a little girl (just go with it, the juxtaposition of inhuman violence and pigtails & scrapped knees is an important literary device). The show wants you to know that these girls are fated to die and that they don't care about their own lives (and you, dear viewer, should because they're innocent little girls and it is cruel that their blood should be shed to maintain the segregationist military state) in case you missed its subtly hints that this was the case it will also beat you about the head with it to make sure you get that they're going to die and they don't care. Then, perhaps more successfully it will show through exposure to MC they actually don't want to die, despite being conditioned, socially and medically to march onwards towards their noble deaths. 


The show has some motifs that it plays heavily on, I found the visuals of catching people who were falling and the changes to Ctholly's hair to be really sweet and emotive. Although, the age gap between MC and Ctholly is more than a little problematic, something which the show seems to deal with by presenting him as "youthful" when he is rather more likely twice her age.


Like Saikano, Gunslinger Girl and Neon Genesis Evangelion the show does raise some pretty deep questions, unfortunately it is rather less successful than any of them in dealing with them. The pacing really does not help nor does the fact that the story relies so heavily on the stock archetypes to paper over the fact that it didn't bother to show you character motivations. Here's a character that appears to be asocial and is incapable of emoting, but is also fiercely loyal to the characters they have glomped onto... so... that's why she did what she did, it's her archetype, not her character...  


If you want to enjoy it watch the ending once and do not think about it again shut down your mind and enjoy the bwaaah. Unfortunately if you allow yourself that moment to analyse what just happened it falls apart. I got teary at the emotional crescendo, it set up the dilemma, the choice was made, the love was strong, the sacrifice was real....... We see the hole that is left in the lives of the characters that remain, we see that the sacrifice did not save the world. Had the show had a run time of 22:39 it would have been a fine ending.... 


But... the credits roll over an epilogue... The epilogue exposes the pap, the cowardly retreat from all of the impact of the ending and an infuriating retreat from the theme of the entire show. 


[/SPOILERS]

This is one of those series that left me with conflicting opinions.  Because, it's not that it was bad, I did enjoy it, but it could have been so much better.
The premise is great.  I had really high hopes after reading the synopsis.  It sounded really interesting and unique.  And it was, it's just that they underutilized that premise.  They chose to focus a bit to much on the love between Willem and Chtholly.  I didn't mind it's inclusion, it just ended up overpowering the main story.
The problem I had was the series left me wanting more.  Iwanted to know more backstory and history of the events leading up to what is happening now.  I wanted to see more of the surface and the monsters they talked so much about.  I wanted to see the fight against the monsters progressing.  It was all too glossed over, leaving too many gaps and questions.

Okay gotta admit this one duped me more than any other series since Madoka Magica. I was expecting something lighter and bittersweet, it delivers and then some.
Art: For the story and style it doesn’t really fit. Its trying to turn genre conventions on their heads.
Character: Pretty decent cast but too diverse with not enough time to flesh them out. I have no idea why but a lot of them became cardboard cutouts halfway through the show, episode 5 in particular. They say things nobody would say and it comes off terrible. The authors naming sense is also pretty bad. I’ve read some weird names thatwere Tolkien inspired but holy crap does this have some bad names that don’t follow the rules of language. 


Story: The story was trying to be deep and fails at it. It has a lot of melodrama that disappoints. Again a lot of the problems occur after the fourth episode. Also since I don’t have anywhere else to complain about it what the hell is up with this title. It sounds like he couldn’t decide between 3 titles and decided to combine them into one ridiculously long monstrosity.


Sound: Pretty good music but nothing really stood out to me and hit me in the feels. 


Overall: I came in with high expectations that sadly the show couldn’t fulfill. I wouldn’t recommend it or watch it with someone who hasn’t seen it.

Shuumatsu has quite a small impression in the starting few episodes. It explores the Tragedy genre which we have seen quite few in recent Light Novels. Shuumatsu is essentially a Light Novel adaptation, with it's long dialogues and with somewhat nice lore.
It starts off soft within the first episode, with no action nor fast paced scenes. But later on, we'll see some dabs of H.P Lovecraft. With it's dark tone of morality and Eldritch "Abominatons'. And yes, Lovecraftian Abominations as we progress through the story and uncover the story behind our Heroine Ctholly (The influence is strong) and our main Character, the last Emnetwith. 
It'snot a bad anime nor it is the best. But, it doesn't hurt to watch it.

Be sure to read the Light Novels as the anime has yet to adapt the recent releases.

Hidden gem of the season. This is one of the few light novel adaptations I've genuinely enjoyed. Don't let the long title or ridiculous sounding name turn you off. It was the only anime this season to actually make me feel emotion. Series that hide their depth under a glossy exterior are a real treat to find. Reminded me a lot of Re Zero in that regard. Overall, this show is average. The songs in this show made me gave it a 6/10 though.

IMPORTANT NOTE: This is my very first anime review so please don't judge me too harshly on this.
If you're a fan of KEY's products like I am and like stories that involve drama, tragedy, and emotional heartbreak then you will definitely like this anime. However, if you were expecting something more out of this anime like I was then you're pretty much going to be disappointed because of the amount of wasted potential this anime had. From my point of view the reason for this is because of how the story was held back through certain elements of the plot. Now I haven't read allthe volumes of the LNs this anime is based on, but even if I did I doubt it would change my opinion very much. So I'm just going to be straight up honest of why this anime ended up disappointing me the most this season.


WHAT THIS ANIME DID WRONG...

The setting of this anime alone is enough to catch you're interest. We are presented to a world where humanity was wiped out and is now populated by furries. We are then introduced to Willem, the last living human in the world along with the fairies, or leprechauns, magical soldiers that are all female created to fight the monstrous beasts that have appeared around the world in which normal soldiers cannot destroy. Soon afterward Willem is selected to be the fairies' "Commanding Officer" and father figure partly to his knowledge and experience with Mud Weapons, the magic weapons used by the fairies use to to destroy the beasts.


At first glance this seems like an anime with the potential to be something great despite a relatively generic setting we've seen before. Unfortunately though, the interesting plot elements and ideas of story has end up suffering from poor execution. The the further you watch the series you begin to notice problems with the overall plot of the story that never really get fully explained or resolved. And the reason for that is because show focuses far too much on the past of this world's setting and not so much on the present.


For example, we're shown how the beasts came to be but we're never told of why exactly they're a threat to the world. So in the end you can't but think that these beasts are just annoying pests that the army just feels obligated to get rid of. Another problem is Elq, a character that share's a special connection to both the world's past and to the fairies. Throughout the show we are told where the fairies came from along with her relationship with Chtholly, and that's it. Unless I missed something we're never really told what Elq's goals are or why she was so focused on Chtholly aside from what we already know. So in the end you're left asking, "What exactly is was point of Elq's character?".


One would argue that you would have to read the LNs, especially after Volume 3, to really understand the story. While that isn't necessarily a bad thing, the problem is that viewers shouldn't have to rely on the LNs to understand the whole picture. The anime should be doing that for them, which sadly did not.


Another big problem with this anime is its lack of focus and lack of tension. Putting aside the last two episodes we see only a handful of battles between the fairies and the beasts. Most of the anime's focus is at home where the fairies are growing up. In any other story I wouldn't mind this but when the story gives the impression that it's suppose to be a war drama, the focus should be on the battlefront and not so much at home.


Now some fans will argue that this anime is not a war drama or even an action series, it's suppose to be a tragedy. While they're not entirely wrong, they're not exactly right either because a war drama is a form of tragedy. A tragedy doesn't have to be about drama and emotional heartbreak. It can be about the loss of youth, innocence, or even life. And since this story features characters who are part of the military and are fighting against a certain enemy, it counts as a war drama. A poorly executed one at that.


If you're going to have a war drama story that involves soldiers and any sort of conflict you need to have three things:


1. Who or what are the characters fighting against?

2. What are the characters fighting for?

3. Most importantly, how will the experiences in battle affect the characters both in body in mind and how will they deal with it both during and after the war?


All three of these things are needed in a war drama. If you just have one or the other it's not going to work. This anime shows what the characters are fighting against but we're never told what they are fighting for or how they deal with what they experienced after it's all over. Instead, the anime decides to focus more on Willem's and Chtholly's relationship, how the other fairies interact with the outside world, and discovering the past.


Again, this would be fine in any other story but the problem here is that the anime is not focusing on rather the real problem, which is the beasts. And because it's not explained why they're such a threat, since the rest of the world doesn't to be really concerned about them, there is a severe lack of tension. We're given no reason to care about the world should it fall to the beasts.


And in the end, it feels more like an insult than a sad ending because nothing changes after the big finale. The anime basically ends the way it started, making you feel like you just wasted nearly 300 minutes of your time for nothing. A few characters die and life just goes on like their deaths meant nothing. Seriously, what kind of story is that? What kind of message is that suppose to give?


WHAT THIS ANIME DID RIGHT...

Despite all my problems, I did like some of the things this anime did have. The setting and the entire concept was enough to get me interested and it stayed that way throughout the whole show. I also really liked the romance between the main two characters partly because I'm a sucker for tsunderes but also because of how believable it was.


Willem's character was also a major plus for this show. You can feel his guilt on the being the very last human being in the world and how he failed to keep his promise with those he knew in his past life. You can see that he wants a second chance to have the life he never had and how he sees the opportunity to obtain through the fairies he takes care of. It's easy to understand why he cares about them so much although some of his reactions were over exaggerated and in my opinion out of character.


Chtholly was also a nice character but the whole degeneration of her mind thing bugged me because it felt it was only holding her character back from being a great one for the sake of emotional heartbreak. In other words, it just didn't have any kind of real impact on me.


The other characters are great as well but since most of them don't get sufficient enough screen time there's not very much reason to care about them. Personally, I think it would have been more interesting if an entire division of these fairy soldiers had been created consisting of both males and females instead of having a Loli's paradise. It would have fascinating to see how they "grow up".


The Mud Weapons were interesting concepts but I think it would have been really cool if the military had been able to make firearm versions. Imagine a scene where normal rifle has no effect on a beast but is then that beast is blown in half but a Mud version of that same rifle. That would have been sick.


The art is excellent but not really spectacular and the songs were a nice touch but the music score  fell rather short.


Overall, the anime does have its good moments but it suffers from poor execution and lack of focus.


WHAT COULD HAVE MADE THIS ANIME BETTER?

Well, better execution for one and focusing more on the bigger issue for another. Maybe even give a better story. The story needed to be about the fairies and their experiences in battle, them becoming aware of themselves, and finding a reason to live. It should not just be about Willem and Chtholly or about how humanity was wiped out because in the end past no longer matters. It's done! Over with! Time to move on!


One of the things I like to do going all the way back when I was a kid was to watch a movie and imagine characters from another setting in the same film. For example, when The Lord of the Rings first came out I used to watch it while imagining The Legend of Zelda characters in it. For this, let me use a movie example to give you an idea of what I feel this anime should have been about.


If I would rewrite this story based on how I reviewed it, the movie I would use as an example would be the 2002 war film "We Were Soldiers". That movie did an excellent job of having the three crucial things of a war drama that I listed above. In addition, it also did an excellent job of balancing out the effects of war between the battlefield and at home.


This anime could have been very much like "We Were Soldiers", but it ended up sacrificing one crucial part of the story for the sake of another. You can have romance, drama, and emotional heartbreak in a war drama, but the main focus needs to be on the battlefront. This isn't impossible with what this anime had to offer. I know it can work and I'm going to into further detail on why it can in my "Anime That Deserved Better" topic that I will post later on in this forum.


If you're a fan of this anime and are curious about the movie "We Were Soldiers" here's my suggestion. Watch the movie, then watch again. Only this time watch it while imagining this anime's characters playing the same roles in that film. Then maybe you'll see why why I feel this anime deserved better than what it got.


I'm DirectorK and until next time, stay tuned.

A nice series, that I enjoyed, it has it's ups and downs, but despite a few hicups it was well done, I really hope we get a second season.
Story:   it's hard to say much without spoiling, but in a world where most people are animals, or orcs and such, a girl and a boy meet up and their story among others.   I liked it, there was a lot of depth in there that we find out about as the story progresses.

Enjoyment and overall:   This is a rather well developed world, with a good story I feel.   I'ts nice bit of fantasy, one of the better anime this season and suggest a look if your curious.

I am reviewing this anime as an independent work and not as something to watch with knowledge of the light novel in mind.

Not really...I still don't know what Venerum is and it got mentioned a lot. Why do furries hate human-looking creatures so much? I can't think of a logical reason why, really.What did the MC do most of the series? Live with a bunch of little girls and being depressed.

This didn't become something I dropped because I at least wanted to know where this show was going. However, I was definitely not hyped every week to see this show.

Frist, let me describe this anime in a nutshell: When you are making a serious, epic drama - but then your manager come in, and tell you that you just ran out of money, and need to turn your work into something that will 100% make good sales (rom-com harem), and quickly.
Yes, this series is totally like this. Absolute amazing, steampunk world of airships and floating isles. Beautiful artwork, both backgrounds and characters. Grim setting with a stern focus on racism, war, and psychological/morale aspect. After watching the first episode, you may think "oh, this looks like the Title of the Year!"...
...And then, we cometo the plot and how it is presented here. Well, i must say even Gate series creators, implemented the fanservice more naturally that it is done here. The world of heavy drama, epic fights, deaths, and difficult morale choices? Lets make some epic adventures series that would be worshipped for decades by a loyal community? Nope -  lets add maids, lolis, lolis with superpowers, and outright rom-com/harem fancervice cliches. Oh, and how can you forget the massive plotholes!\n\n
Verdict: This anime tries to be both a serious throught-provoking drama, like Shinsekai Yori or Sidonia no Kishi, and a light-hearted comedy with some fantasy adventures as a background, like KonoSuba or Zero no Tsukaima. At the same time. Which is simply impossible, and is the exact reason why this one title is a fail. You can't seat on two chairs at once.\n\n
Rating: I rated this anime 7/10, but thats almost exclusively for the first episode, which is absolutely magnificent. Otherwise this is 5/10 at best.

It's a so so anime, not bad not good. 
The rhythm little slow but the author doesn't use it to explore his universe, it doesn't tell you many things about the characters, he gives you facts with no real subtlety.
This anime plays on easy feels (young love, brutal ending) and looses itself then comes back on track. This slice of life / action type has been has been done better many times before. The writting/pace feels like a good old like Chrno Crusade but misses its target and won't certainly be remembered.
Characters are one sided and underdeveloped. There are not many things to understand ofit but what is told. \n\n
I think if you want a simple story and have nothing to watch, it could a nice catch.

This anime's idea had so much potential. It was very disappointing seeing a storyline very poorly executed. The story goes on in a confusing and unclear way.
In many occasions they mention terms from the light novel that the anime never explained carefully. I disliked that.
I disliked how badly the story was told, and knowing that it could,ve been way better. It sometimes seemed like it was made in a rush.
But i liked the love story, the MC desin, attitude, personality. He's not a coward at all, and has very strong morals. The rest of the characters are just average fine.
The female characters are all verybeautiful yet basic and have very predictible behavior.\n\n
This could've been a tremendous anime for sure. It has very good plot pints but fails to develop them in a more strongly and impacting way towards the end.\n
A score of 6, because i like romance. But the anime could've been way better. Still very enjoyable, if you like rom-com, action mixed with a little drama, couple problems..you'll find something to hang from while watching this anime.
